job_title: Manager of Corporate Partnerships in New York, NY
pros: Great culture, diversity, low pressure environment, 35 hour work week
cons: As expect for a non-profit, low salaries and minimal growth opportunities

review_title: Working here was a huge mistake
pros: I really did not enjoy my time at this organization and can't think of any pros.
cons:
I worked directly with all departments as part of my role. The education and sports teams are full of chill, dedicated people who seem to enjoy their job.

The development and marketing teams seem absolutely miserable. And the reason is likely the Executive Director, who is one of the most disrespectful and unprofessional individuals I've ever worked with (which aligns exactly with their reputation in the sector). Zero to yelling in mere seconds. Always trash talking the development team. Sometimes it was so ridiculous I just had to laugh. They once screamed, "I'm not upset!" at me. Everyone seems afraid of the ED which creates a really strange culture of telephone and tip-toeing in lieu of direct, honest, and respectful conversation.

Leadership overall is disorganized and chaotic. HR is contracted and I had issue after issue with getting insurance set up, accessing time management software, etc. Really basic stuff. 

I would stay far away from this organization if your role will bring you into even occasional contact with leadership.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Just as fun as the programs and shows are is the same enthusiasm with my co-workers.
cons: Not much to say as my position was seasonal.

pros: CPF is currently remote during the pandemic.

pros: Great music, great shows, great people to work with

review_title: Great mission and lots of heart
pros: Great organization and people are like family. Mission based work is fulfilling.
cons: Staff are overworked and under paid. Emotionally taxing. Leaderships seems disorganized and rarely on the same page.

pros: Supportive and fun coworkers and good pay, very educational

job_title: Ride Operator in New Orleans, LA

pros: Fantastic mission that the organization works diligently towards, SummerStage perks, ED (although prickly) genuinely cares and respects her employees. Good benefits and friendly (non-senior staff) colleagues.
cons: During my exit interview, HR audibly gasped, apologized to me, and said "I would've quit, too." Zero management training which results in awful micromanagement, martyrdom, and generally irresponsible people in senior level positions. The Arts/Sports/Education segments of the org seem to have it together, but anywhere near executive office/development are a disaster. Cold, fake senior staff who blatantly disrespect their staff. I worked overtime regularly, was discouraged from taking my vacation time, and my supervisor said things to me like "if you want to do a workload comparison I'll always win, so keep that to yourself" and "you have to be careful what you say to women employees, because they'll go running to HR" and even went so far as to call me "snotty and unprofessional" on multiple occasions. Take this with a grain of salt if you will, but at the very least there needs to be sensitivity and management training stat.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: The organization has a great mission.  There are some very nice people here.
cons: The HR department is virtually non-existent.  Summerstage is the only department with a public face.  The rest, i.e. education, sports and PfP are severely under-resourced, and prone to infiltration by despotic managers with only their own career-advancement in mind.  I must have put in hundreds of hours of unpaid overtime.  Employees are over extended and under resourced.  People only talk about the departmental problems amongst themselves because the upper-management is not interested.

job_title: Seasonal Tennis Instructor in Flushing, NY
pros: Rewarding to teach sports to children. Programs are sponsored by various athletic brands. Good summer job for college students back from school.
cons: Focus seems to be on the golf program with seasonal Part-time golf instructors starting at $25/hour, while Full-time tennis instructors start at around $10. They hire inexperienced "instructors" who cannot teach or play the sport in lieu of seasoned veterans to justify paying less, but at the cost of the quality of the program. The summer program for beginner tennis has its politics where promotions are rewarded to the favored over the deserving. Tennis staff must carry at least 30 lbs of equipment from site to site via public transit or carpool, whereas other program staff have equipment locked away on-site.

review_title: STAY AWAY OR IF ALREADY THERE, RUN
pros: There are no pros except that because so many people are unhappy, you know you're not alone.
cons: If you're interested in working for and with people with no sense of racial nuance, no commitment to diversity, no belief in social justice values (while pretending that their work is about equity), and no interest in listening to people of color on their staff then this is place for you.   This organization excels at being mediocre at best, and at worst a mentally abusive workplace with a senior management team that are both bumbling and incompetent while also being untrustworthy and manipulative.   Current CEO is not Allison Tocci, it is Heather Lubov.

pros: Most salaries are competitive with other nonprofits, but there is no pay equity within the organization. Long time staff who are incapable managers continue to be employed and compensated at over six figures, while there is no room for growth for lower level employees who are paid badly. There is no HR and nothing happens to senior level staff when complaints are made against them.
cons: No system to give feedback, tyrannical and/or incompetent senior people. Those who complain about conditions are pushed out where those who do the bare minimum or less who are seen as compliant are rewarded or at least left alone.

pros:

Free SummerStage concerts and events access

Favoritism among some senior staff

pros: Every single employee is a talented coach and great person. They make work enjoyable. In addition, working with kids is a rewarding experience.
cons: The temperature can get over 100, but track is only cancelled for thunderstorms or heavy rain. In addition, kids can be difficult to deal with at times.

pros:
Great for new coaches. They provide quality training to all new and returning coaches each year. 
They hand pick each coach and put together teams that work well together.
Don't have to go out finding students. Only job is to teach energetic kids.
cons: Can be taxing on the body since all locations are out doors, and have to travel with equipment to each location. But nothing different from most tennis coaching.
